Section 1:
EXEMPT
S.B. 494
(ON BEHALF OF THE OFFICE OF FINANCE
IN THE OFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR)
MAY 15, 2025
____________
Referred to Committee on Health and Human Services
SUMMARY—Makes revisions relating to health and human
services. (BDR 18-1116)
FISCAL NOTE: Effect on Local Government: May have Fiscal Impact.
Effect on the State: Executive Budget.
~
EXPLANATION – Matter in bolded italics is new; matter between brackets [omitted material] is material to be omitted.
AN ACT relating to state government; creating the Nevada Health
Authority; creating certain divisions and offices within
the Authority; providing for the appointment of officers
and the employment of staff for the Authority;
establishing requirements governing procurement by the
Authority; creating the Nevada Health Authority Gift
Fund; prescribing the duties of the Authority and its
divisions and officers; transferring to the Authority the
responsibility for operating various programs and
administering various provisions; revising the name of
certain agencies; revising certain terminology; eliminating
the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy of the
Department of Health and Human Services; revising
provisions governing the operation of the Public
Employees’ Benefits Program; revising the membership
and duties of the Board of Directors of the Silver State
Health Insurance Exchange; and providing other matters
properly relating thereto.
Legislative Counsel’s Digest:
1 Existing law creates the Department of Health and Human Services, which
2 consists of the Aging and Disability Services Division, the Division of Public and
3 Behavioral Health, the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services, the Division
4 of Child and Family Services and the Division of Health Care Financing and
5 Policy. (NRS 232.300) This bill creates a new department within the Executive
-
*SB494*
– 2 –
6 Department of the State Government known as the Nevada Health Authority to
7 assume certain responsibilities of the Department of Health and Human Services
8 and other entities related to the management of certain public health insurance
9 plans, the licensing and regulation of certain persons and entities involved in the
10 provision of health care and the regulation of sanitation in food establishments and
11 certain other locations.
12 Section 18 of this bill creates and establishes the purposes of the Authority, and
13 section 32 of this bill changes the name of the Department to the Department of
14 Human Services. Section 18 provides that the Authority consists of: (1) the
15 Medicaid Division; (2) the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division; and
16 (3) the Consumer Health Division. Section 19 of this bill requires the Governor to
17 appoint a Director of the Authority who possesses certain qualifications. Sections
18 20-23 and 29 of this bill provide for the appointment of officers and the
19 employment of staff for the Authority, including an administrator of each division
20 of the Authority. Sections 24 and 79 of this bill exempt the Authority from
21 provisions of law governing state procurement, with certain exceptions, and section
22 24 prescribes requirements governing procurement by the Authority. Sections 24
23 and 61 of this bill provide for the confidentiality of certain information submitted
24 to the Authority during the procurement process. Section 25 of this bill authorizes:
25 (1) the sharing of confidential information within the Authority; and (2) the
26 Authority to share confidential information with certain agencies of local
27 governments in certain circumstances. Sections 26 and 34 of this bill transfer from
28 the Department to the Authority the authority to administer certain programs for
29 persons with developmental disabilities. Section 28 of this bill requires the Director
30 or the Director’s designee to adopt each state plan required by the Federal
31 Government for the administration of any program for which the Authority or a
32 division thereof is responsible. Section 31 of this bill creates the Nevada Health
33 Authority Gift Fund to hold gifts, grants and other property which the Authority is
34 authorized to accept. Sections 113 and 227 of this bill require the deposit of certain
35 money in the Fund. Section 36 of this bill updates the name of the Department of
36 Health and Human Services Gift Fund, which is created by existing law, to conform
37 to the change in the name of the Department. (NRS 232.355)
38 Existing law requires the Office of Science, Innovation and Technology in the
39 Office of the Governor to administer the Graduate Medical Education Grant
40 Program, which is a program to award grants to institutions in this State seeking to
41 create, expand or retain programs for residency training and postdoctoral
42 fellowships for physicians. (NRS 223.631-223.639) Sections 2-8 and 26 of this bill
43 transfer to the Consumer Health Division the responsibility for administering the
44 Program.
45 Existing law requires the Board of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program to
46 establish the Program to provide group life, accident or health insurance, or any
47 combination thereof, to employees of the State Government. (NRS 287.043)
48 Section 68 of this bill places the Board within the Authority and makes revisions
49 governing the appointment of the members of the Board. Section 69 of this bill
50 transfers from the Board to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for
51 appointing the Executive Officer of the Program. Section 70 of this bill requires the
52 Executive Officer to submit to the Authority a report regarding the administration
53 and operation of the Program, in addition to certain other entities that currently
54 receive the report. Section 71 of this bill provides that the appointment of officers
55 and unclassified employees to administer the Program is subject to the approval of
56 the Director of the Authority. Sections 72-74 of this bill authorize the Board to
57 utilize certain services of the Authority, including procurement services.
58 Existing law requires: (1) the Department to administer Medicaid and the
59 Children’s Health Insurance Program; and (2) the Division of Health Care
60 Financing and Policy of the Department to perform certain duties related to the
-
*SB494*
– 3 –
61 administration of those programs. (Chapter 422 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 93-96,
62 113-117 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department and the Director of the
63 Department to the Medicaid Division and the Director of the Authority the
64 responsibility for administering Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance
65 Program. Sections 32, 34 and 35 of this bill abolish the Division of Health Care
66 Financing and Policy, and sections 94 and 359 transfer the authority, duties and
67 responsibilities of that Division to the Medicaid Division. Section 86 of this bill
68 authorizes the Authority to delegate to other governmental entities the
69 responsibility for making determinations of eligibility for Medicaid and the
70 Children’s Health Insurance Program. Section 87 of this bill creates the Office of
71 the Medicaid Inspector General within the Authority to perform certain duties to
72 ensure the integrity of Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program and
73 to prevent waste, fraud and abuse in those programs. Sections 66, 88-91 and 371 of
74 this bill transfer or provide to the Authority certain responsibilities related to the
75 administration of those programs. Sections 101-104, 109 and 110 of this bill
76 establish provisions governing the qualifications, supervision and activities of the
77 Administrator of the Medicaid Division, which are similar to the qualifications,
78 supervision and activities of the Administrator of the Division of Health Care
79 Financing and Policy. (NRS 422.2354-422.2364, 422.2372) Sections 105-108, 111
80 and 112 of this bill transfer to the Director certain responsibilities relating to
81 Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program, including the responsibility
82 for adopting regulations governing those programs. Section 116 requires any
83 contract for the expenditure of federal money under Medicaid to be signed by the
84 Director. Section 118 of this bill requires the Authority to: (1) include on an
85 Internet website maintained by the Authority certain information to allow recipients
86 of Medicaid through managed care to compare available plans; and (2) develop and
87 implement a beneficiary support system for such recipients of Medicaid. Section
88 371 repeals certain fiscal duties previously performed by the Administrator of the
89 Division of Health Care Financing and Policy.
90 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144-146, 194, 217-224, 245-247, 250, 260, 276, 325-327
91 and 360 of this bill transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to
92 the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division and from the Department of
93 Health and Human Services to the Nevada Health Authority, as applicable, the
94 responsibilities for credentialing and regulating: (1) programs for the treatment of
95 persons who commit domestic violence; (2) health care facilities and certain entities
96 involved in the provision of personal care services; (3) nontransplant anatomical
97 donation organizations; (4) naprapaths; and (5) medical laboratories and their
98 personnel. Section 143 of this bill authorizes the State Board of Health to establish
99 fees for the credentialing functions and certain other functions of the Health Care
100 Purchasing and Compliance Division. Sections 26, 34 and 162-171 of this bill
101 transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to the Health Care
102 Purchasing and Compliance Division the responsibility for administering
103 provisions governing health and safety at health care facilities, including the
104 reporting of sentinel events. Section 35 reduces the number of deputy
105 administrators in the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to account for the
106 duties removed from that Division.
107 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144, 145, 147-152, 154-160, 180-187, 197-200, 226-238,
108 240-244 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department to the Authority the
109 responsibility for administering; (1) the State Program for Oral Health; (2)
110 provisions governing health information technology; (3) the programs to increase
111 public awareness of health care information concerning hospitals and surgical
112 centers for ambulatory patients in this State; (4) provisions governing the reporting
113 of information relating to the cost of certain prescription drugs and certain
114 information concerning pharmacies; (5) the Nevada Health Facilities Assistance
115 Act, which establishes a program to construct new health facilities in this State; and
-
*SB494*
– 4 –
116 (6) certain requirements to ensure the quality of care offered by hospitals in this
117 State and the financial stability of such hospitals.
118 Existing law: (1) creates the Patient Protection Commission within the Office
119 of the Director of the Department; and (2) requires the Commission to perform
120 certain duties to improve the quality, accessibility and affordability of health care in
121 this State. (NRS 439.908, 439.918) Sections 26, 34, 172 and 173 of this bill
122 transfer the Commission to the Consumer Health Division. Section 173 also
123 transfers from the Governor to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for
124 appointing the members of the Commission. Sections 174 and 175 of this bill
125 require the Commission to make certain recommendations and submit certain
126 reports to the Director of the Authority.
127 Existing law requires the Department to establish an all-payer claims database
128 of information relating to health insurance claims resulting from medical, dental or
129 pharmacy benefits provided in this State. (NRS 439B.835) Section 29 creates the
130 Office of Data Analytics within the Authority, and sections 26, 34, 202-204 and
131 359 of this bill transfer to the Office the responsibility for operating the all-payer
132 claims database.
133 Existing law: (1) requires the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to
134 enforce provisions governing sanitation and food establishments under certain
135 circumstances; and (2) requires each county where the Division provides such
136 enforcement to pay an assessment to the Division. (NRS 439.4905, chapters 444
137 and 446 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 206-208 and 210-216 of this bill transfer to the
138 Authority the authority to enforce provisions governing sanitation and food
139 establishments, and sections 30 and 153 of this bill require counties who currently
140 pay to the Division an assessment for those functions to instead pay the assessment
141 to the Authority.
142 Existing law requires the State Board of Health to license and regulate music
143 therapists and dietitians. (Chapters 640D and 640E of NRS) Sections 26, 283-297
144 and 300-323 of this bill transfer to the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance
145 Division the responsibilities for issuing and renewing licenses to those
146 professionals and enforcing provisions of law and regulations governing
147 those professionals and leave the authority to adopt regulations governing those
148 professions with the State Board.
149 Existing law creates the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange. (NRS
150 695I.200) Existing law requires the Exchange to: (1) create and administer a state-
151 based health insurance exchange; (2) facilitate the purchase and sale of qualified
152 health plans; (3) provide for the establishment of a program to help certain small
153 employers in Nevada in facilitating the enrollment of employees in qualified health
154 plans; and (4) perform all other duties required pursuant to the federal Patient
155 Protection and Affordable Care Act, the federal Health Care and Education
156 Reconciliation Act of 2010 and any amendments to or regulations or guidance
157 issued pursuant to those Acts. (Pub. L. No. 111-148, Pub. L. No. 111-152; NRS
158 695I.200, 695I.210) The Exchange is governed by the Board of Directors
159 consisting of five voting members appointed by the Governor, one voting member
160 appointed by the Senate Majority Leader, one voting member appointed by the
161 Speaker of the Assembly and three ex officio, nonvoting members. (NRS 695I.300)
162 Sections 346-348 of this bill place the Exchange under the authority of the
163 Consumer Health Division. Section 348: (1) reduces the number of members of the
164 Board appointed by the Governor from five to two; (2) adds three heads of agencies
165 whose work relates to public health or health insurance as ex officio, voting
166 members of the Board; and (3) reduces the nonvoting membership of the Board.
167 Sections 349 and 350 of this bill make revisions governing the terms of the
168 members and officers of the Board. Section 352 of this bill transfers from
169 the Board to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for appointing the
170 Executive Director of the Exchange. Sections 351 and 352 of this bill transfer
-
*SB494*
– 5 –
171 certain duties relating to auditing and reports from the Board to the Executive
172 Director. Sections 353 and 354 of this bill transfer certain other duties related to
173 the Exchange to Authority and its Director.
174 Existing law requires the Director of the Department, in consultation with the
175 Commissioner of Insurance and the Executive Director of the Exchange, to design,
176 establish and operate a health benefit plan known as the Public Option. (NRS
177 695K.200) Section 355 of this bill transfers the responsibility for designing,
178 establishing and operating the Public Option to the Director of the Authority.
179 Section 27 of this bill requires the Director and the Authority to take certain
180 actions to facilitate determinations of eligibility for and the selection of plans under
181 Medicaid and certain other public health insurance programs under the jurisdiction
182 of the Authority. Sections 9-13, 38-60, 62, 77, 78, 80, 81, 83, 96-98, 100, 121, 123,
183 125, 128-139, 142, 161, 178, 179, 188, 189, 195, 196, 205, 209, 248, 249, 251-275,
184 277-280, 324, 328-336, 338-341 and 356-358 of this bill make various conforming
185 changes to reflect the authority transferred by the provisions of this bill. Sections
186 32, 34, 38, 46, 99, 122, 127, 239, 287, 307 and 326 of this bill change the name of
187 the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services of the Department to the Division
188 of Social Services of the Department. Sections 33, 37, 82, 119, 120, 123, 124, 126-
189 128 and 368 of this bill revise the terminology to refer to certain programs operated
190 by that Division from “welfare” to “public assistance.” Section 132 revises the term
191 “transitional assistance” to “child care assistance” to describe certain assistance
192 provided pursuant to federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program.
193 Sections 1, 16, 17, 64, 65, 85, 140, 176, 191, 192, 225, 240, 281, 298, 343 and 344
194 of this bill define certain terms, and sections 15, 67, 75, 76, 92, 177, 193, 201, 282,
195 299, 337 and 345 of this bill make conforming changes to indicate the applicability
196 of those definitions. Section 371 eliminates certain definitions that are no longer
197 necessary.
198 Section 361 of this bill transfers to the Authority the duty to carry out any
199 requirements of a bill that is enacted by the Legislature during this session and
200 approved by the Governor to: (1) require the Department of Health and Human
201 Services to operate a program to award money to support projects to address
202 shortages of providers of health care in this State; or (2) impose certain
203 requirements on Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

14 Sec. 5. NRS 223.633 is hereby amended to read as follows:
15 223.633 1. The Advisory Council on Graduate Medical
16 Education is hereby created within the [Office of Science,
17 Innovation and Technology.] Division. The Council consists of:
18 (a) The dean of each medical school in this State that is
19 accredited by the Liaison Committee on Medical Education of the
20 American Medical Association and the Association of American
21 Medical Colleges or their successor organizations, or his or her
22 designee;
23 (b) The dean of each school of osteopathic medicine in this State
24 that is accredited by the Commission on Osteopathic College
25 Accreditation of the American Osteopathic Association or its
26 successor organization, or his or her designee;
27 (c) Two members appointed by the Governor who are
28 physicians licensed pursuant to chapter 630 or 633 of NRS;
29 (d) One member appointed by the Governor who represents
30 hospitals located in counties whose population is less than 100,000;
31 (e) One member appointed by the Governor who represents
32 hospitals located in counties whose population is 100,000 or more
33 but less than 700,000;
34 (f) One member appointed by the Governor who represents
35 hospitals located in a county whose population is 700,000 or more;
36 (g) One member appointed by the Governor who represents the
37 medical corps of any of the Armed Forces of the United States;
38 (h) One member appointed by the Governor who represents the
39 Department of [Health and] Human Services; and
40 (i) One member appointed by the Governor who represents the
41 Office of Economic Development in the Office of the Governor.
42 2. In addition to the members appointed by the Governor
43 pursuant to subsection 1, the Governor may appoint two members as
44 the Governor determines necessary to carry out the provisions of
45 NRS 223.631 to 223.639, inclusive.

1 3. After the initial terms, the term of each member of the
2 Council is 3 years, and members shall serve at the pleasure of the
3 Governor.
4 4. Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the Council
5 must be filled in the same manner as the original appointment not
6 later than 30 days after the vacancy occurs.
7 5. The Council shall select from its members a Chair and a
8 Vice Chair who shall hold office for 1 year and who may be
9 reselected.
10 6. The Council shall meet at the call of the Chair as often as
11 necessary to evaluate applications for competitive grants for the
12 Graduate Medical Education Grant Program established pursuant to
13 NRS 223.637 and make recommendations to the [Office of Science,
14 Innovation and Technology] Division concerning the approval of
15 applications for such grants.
16 7. A majority of the members of the Council constitutes a
17 quorum for the transaction of business, and a majority of those
18 members present at any meeting is sufficient for any official action
19 taken by the Council.
20 8. The members of the Council serve without compensation,
21 except that each member is entitled to receive the per diem
22 allowance and travel expenses provided for state officers and
23 employees generally while engaged in the official business of the
24 Council.
25 9. A member of the Council who is an officer or employee of
26 this State or a political subdivision of this State must be relieved
27 from his or her duties without loss of regular compensation to
28 prepare for and attend meetings of the Council and perform any
29 work necessary to carry out the duties of the Council in the most
30 timely manner practicable. A state agency or political subdivision of
31 this State shall not require an officer or employee who is a member
32 of the Council to:
33 (a) Make up the time he or she is absent from work to carry out
34 his or her duties as a member of the Council; or
35 (b) Take annual leave or compensatory time for the absence.

22 Sec. 9. NRS 223.950 is hereby amended to read as follows:
23 223.950 1. The Public Health Resource Office is hereby
24 created within the Office of the Governor.
25 2. The Governor shall appoint a person who is knowledgeable

28 or unclassified service of the State and serves at the pleasure of the
29 Governor.
30 3. The Public Health Resource Office may accept gifts, grants
31 and donations to support its duties.
32 4. The Public Health Resource Office shall:
33 (a) Analyze the existing infrastructure for meeting the public
34 health needs of this State and the relationships between persons and

36 including, without limitation, the Division of Public and Behavioral
37 Health of the Department of [Health and] Human Services, the
38 Nevada Health Authority, local health authorities, providers of
39 health care, health care facilities and nonprofit organizations; and
40 (b) Identify and make recommendations to the Governor, the
41 Legislature, the Director of the Department of [Health and] Human
42 Services , [and] the Administrator of the Division of Public and
43 Behavioral Health of the Department and the Director of the
44 Nevada Health Authority concerning:
45 (1) Unmet needs for public health services;

6 Sec. 10. NRS 226.454 is hereby amended to read as follows:
7 226.454 “Provider of health care” means:
8 1. A physician;
9 2. A physician assistant licensed pursuant to chapter 630 or
10 633 of NRS;
11 3. A dentist;
12 4. A licensed nurse;
13 5. A person who holds a license as an attendant or is certified
14 as an emergency medical technician, advanced emergency medical
15 technician or paramedic pursuant to chapter 450B of NRS;

39 Human Services] Nevada Health Authority and the Medicaid

27 Attorney General may commence an investigation and file a
28 criminal action without leave of court, and has exclusive charge of

34 Sec. 16. “Authority” means the Nevada Health Authority.
35 Sec. 17. “Director” means the Director of the Authority.
36 Sec. 18. 1. The Nevada Health Authority is hereby created
37 as a department within the Executive Department of the State
38 Government.
39 2. The purposes of the Authority are to:
40 (a) Improve access to health care that is safe, of high quality
41 and affordable;
42 (b) Promote the development of a workforce of providers of
43 health care that is sufficient to meet the demand for health care in
44 this State;
-
*SB494*
– 17 –
1 (c) Ensure the availability of affordable health coverage for
2 residents of this State, including, without limitation, current and
3 retired employees of the State Government;
4 (d) Develop effective and efficient systems for delivering health
5 care and value-based strategies for procuring health insurance
6 coverage in the most sustainable and responsive manner possible;
7 and
8 (e) Ensure the long-term stability of Medicaid, the Children’s
9 Health Insurance Program, the Public Employees’ Benefits
10 Program, the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange and the
11 Public Option by minimizing the financial burden of health care
12 on persons who receive health coverage through those programs,
13 the state budget and other residents of this State through the use
14 of measures to contain costs, maximizing the impact of state and
15 federal money and the application of innovative purchasing and
16 contracting strategies.
17 3. The Authority consists of a Director and:
18 (a) The Medicaid Division;
19 (b) The Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division;
20 and
21 (c) The Consumer Health Division.
22 4. The Authority is the sole agency responsible for
23 administering the provisions of law relating to its respective
24 divisions.
25 Sec. 19. The Director:
26 1. Is appointed by, is responsible to, and serves at the
27 pleasure of the Governor.
28 2. Is in the unclassified service of the State.
29 3. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 284.143, shall not
30 engage in any other gainful employment or occupation.
31 4. Must have broad, responsible experience in the field of
32 administration or possess broad management skills or working
33 knowledge of the field of health care or public health
34 administration.
35 5. Must be selected with special reference to his or her
36 training, experience and aptitude for coordinating related
37 functions of public health agencies and public health insurance
38 programs. The Director’s knowledge and abilities should include
39 the following:
40 (a) A comprehensive knowledge of administrative principles,
41 and a working knowledge of principles of public finance and the
42 laws, rules and regulations pertaining to public agencies.
43 (b) Administrative ability to assess the operating efficiency of
44 component agencies and to delegate authority and duties to
45 responsible deputy directors or other personnel of the Authority.
-
*SB494*
– 18 –
1 (c) The ability to organize and clearly present oral and written
2 findings and recommendations to the Governor, the Legislature
3 and other officials and agencies.
4 Sec. 20. 1. The Director may employ, within the limits of
5 legislative appropriations, such staff as is necessary to the
6 performance of the Director’s duties.
7 2. Any provider of health care who is employed by the
8 Authority for purposes related to Medicaid or the Children’s
9 Health Insurance Program must sign a form agreeing to:

11 personal interests of the provider of health care and the interests
12 of Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program; and
13 (b) If a conflict of interest described in paragraph (a) arises:
14 (1) Report the conflict to the Administrator of the Medicaid
15 Division of the Authority; and
16 (2) Recuse himself or herself from action or deliberation on
17 the matter in the capacity of his or her employment with the
18 Authority.

20 or the Director’s designee, is responsible for appointing and
21 removing subordinate officers and employees of the Authority.

36 Sec. 30. 1. Unless an exemption is approved pursuant to
37 subsection 3, each county shall pay an assessment to the
38 Authority, in an amount determined by the Authority, for the costs
39 of services provided in that county by the Authority pursuant to
40 chapters 444 and 446 of NRS, regardless of whether the county
41 has a local health authority.
42 2. Each county shall pay the assessment to the Nevada
43 Health Authority in quarterly installments that are due on the first
44 day of the first month of each calendar quarter.
-
*SB494*
– 26 –
1 3. A county may submit a proposal to the Governor for the
2 county to carry out the services that would otherwise be provided
3 by the Authority pursuant to chapters 444 and 446 of NRS and the
4 regulations adopted pursuant to those chapters. If the Governor
5 approves the proposal, the Governor shall submit a
6 recommendation to the Interim Finance Committee to exempt the
7 county from the assessment required pursuant to subsection 1.
8 The Interim Finance Committee, upon receiving the
9 recommendation from the Governor, shall consider the proposal
10 and determine whether to approve the exemption. In considering
11 whether to approve the exemption, the Interim Finance Committee
12 shall consider, among other things, the best interests of the State,
13 the effect of the exemption and the intent of the Legislature in
14 requiring the assessment to be paid by each county.
15 4. An exemption that is approved by the Interim Finance
16 Committee pursuant to subsection 3 must not become effective
17 until at least 6 months after that approval.
18 5. A county that receives approval pursuant to subsection 3 to
19 carry out the services that would otherwise be provided by the
20 Authority pursuant to chapters 444 and 446 of NRS and the
21 regulations adopted pursuant to those chapters shall carry out
22 those services in the manner set forth in those chapters and
23 regulations.

26 Sec. 31. 1. Except for gifts or grants specifically accounted
27 for in another fund, all gifts or grants of money or other property
28 which the divisions of the Authority are authorized to accept must
29 be accounted for in the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund,
30 which is hereby created as a special revenue fund. The Fund is a
31 continuing fund without reversion. The Authority may establish
32 such accounts in the Fund as are necessary to account properly
33 for gifts received. All such money received by the divisions of the
34 Authority must be deposited in the State Treasury for credit to the
35 Fund. The money in the Fund must be paid out on claims as other
36 claims against the State are paid. Unless otherwise specifically
37 provided by statute, claims against the Fund must be approved by
38 the Director or the Director’s delegate.
39 2. Gifts of property other than money may be sold or
40 exchanged when this is deemed by the head of the agency
41 responsible for the gift to be in the best interest of the agency. The
42 sale price must not be less than 90 percent of the value determined
43 by a qualified appraiser appointed by the head of the agency. All
44 money received from the sale must be deposited in the State
45 Treasury to the credit of the appropriate gift account in the
-

1 Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund. The money may be spent only
2 for the purposes of the agency named in the title of the account.

2 111.779 1. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 21.090 and

12 Sec. 48. NRS 146.070 is hereby amended to read as follows:
13 146.070 1. All or part of the estate of a decedent may be set
14 aside without administration by the order of the court as follows:
15 (a) If the value of a decedent’s estate does not exceed $100,000,
16 the estate may be set aside without administration by the order of
17 the court; or
18 (b) If a decedent’s will directs that all or part of the decedent’s
19 estate is to be distributed to the trustee of a nontestamentary trust
20 established by the decedent and in existence at the decedent’s death,
21 the portion of the estate subject to such direction may be set aside
22 without administration. Any portion of a decedent’s estate set aside
23 to the nontestamentary trust pursuant to this paragraph is subject to
24 creditors of the estate unless the petitioner provides proof to the
25 court that the trustee has published or mailed the requisite notice to
26 such creditors on behalf of the nontestamentary trust and settlor
27 pursuant to NRS 164.025.
28 2. Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, the whole
29 estate set aside pursuant to paragraph (a) of subsection 1 must be
30 assigned and set apart in the following order:
31 (a) To the payment of the petitioner’s attorney’s fees and costs
32 incurred relative to the proceeding under this section;
33 (b) To the payment of funeral expenses, expenses of last illness,
34 money owed to the [Department of Health and Human Services]
35 Nevada Health Authority as a result of payment of benefits for
36 Medicaid and creditors, if there are any;
37 (c) To the payment of other creditors, if any; and
38 (d) Any balance remaining to the claimant or claimants entitled
39 thereto pursuant to a valid will of the decedent, and if there is no
40 valid will, pursuant to intestate succession in accordance with
41 chapter 134 of NRS.
42 3. If the value of the estate does not exceed $100,000 and the

-

– 52 –
1 reduction made pursuant to subsection 4 or 5. The court may
2 allocate the entire estate to the surviving spouse, the entire amount

5 4. As to any amount set aside to or for the benefit of the
6 surviving spouse or minor child or minor children of the decedent
7 pursuant to subsection 3, the court must set aside the estate without
8 the payment of creditors except as the court finds necessary to
9 prevent a manifest injustice.
10 5. To prevent an injustice to creditors when there are
11 nonprobate transfers that already benefit the surviving spouse or
12 minor child or minor children of the decedent, the court has the
13 discretion to reduce the amount set aside under subsection 3 to the
14 extent that the value of the estate, when combined with the value of
15 nonprobate transfers, as defined in NRS 111.721, from the decedent
16 to or for the benefit of the surviving spouse or minor child or minor
17 children of the decedent exceeds $100,000.
18 6. In exercising the discretion granted in this section, the court
19 shall consider the needs and resources of the surviving spouse and
20 minor child or minor children, including any assets received by or
21 for the benefit of the surviving spouse or minor child or minor
22 children from the decedent by nonprobate transfers.
23 7. For the purpose of this section, a nonprobate transfer from
24 the decedent to one or more trusts or custodial accounts for the
25 benefit of the surviving spouse or minor child or minor children

27 child or minor children.

33 record on the basis that the requested public book or record contains
34 information that is confidential if the governmental entity can
35 redact, delete, conceal or separate, including, without limitation,
36 electronically, the confidential information from the information
37 included in the public book or record that is not otherwise
38 confidential.
39 4. If requested, a governmental entity shall provide a copy of a
40 public record in an electronic format by means of an electronic
41 medium. Nothing in this subsection requires a governmental entity
42 to provide a copy of a public record in an electronic format or by
43 means of an electronic medium if:
44 (a) The public record:
45 (1) Was not created or prepared in an electronic format; and
-
*SB494*
– 72 –
1 (2) Is not available in an electronic format; or
2 (b) Providing the public record in an electronic format or by
3 means of an electronic medium would:
4 (1) Give access to proprietary software; or
5 (2) Require the production of information that is confidential
6 and that cannot be redacted, deleted, concealed or separated from
7 information that is not otherwise confidential.
8 5. An officer, employee or agent of a governmental entity who
9 has legal custody or control of a public record:
10 (a) Shall not refuse to provide a copy of that public record in the
11 medium that is requested because the officer, employee or agent has
12 already prepared or would prefer to provide the copy in a different
13 medium.
14 (b) Except as otherwise provided in NRS 239.030, shall, upon
15 request, prepare the copy of the public record and shall not require
16 the person who has requested the copy to prepare the copy himself
17 or herself.

12 of any deed made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, any
13 person specified in subsection 4 is entitled to have the property
14 reconveyed upon the receipt by the county treasurer of payment by
15 or on behalf of that person of an amount equal to the taxes accrued,
16 together with any costs, penalties and interest legally chargeable
17 against the property. A reconveyance may not be made after
18 expiration of the 90-day period specified in NRS 361.603.
19 4. Property may be reconveyed pursuant to subsection 3 to one
20 or more of the persons specified in the following categories, or to
21 one or more persons within a particular category, as their interests
22 may appear of record:
23 (a) The owner.
24 (b) The beneficiary under a note and deed of trust.
25 (c) The mortgagee under a mortgage.
26 (d) The creditor under a judgment.
27 (e) The person to whom the property was assessed.
28 (f) The person holding a contract to purchase the property before
29 its conveyance to the county treasurer.
30 (g) The Director of the [Department of Health and Human
31 Services] Nevada Health Authority if the owner has received or is
32 receiving any benefits from Medicaid.
33 (h) The successor in interest of any person specified in this
34 subsection.
35 (i) A municipality that holds a lien against the property.
36 5. The provisions of this section apply to land held in trust by a
37 county treasurer on or after April 17, 1971.

24 or local governmental agency to which the Authority has
25 delegated a function.

27 pursuant to subsection 1 shall comply with the relevant provisions
28 of this chapter to the same extent as the Authority.

7 assistance on behalf of the recipient an amount not to exceed the
8 amount of public assistance incorrectly paid to the recipient, if the
9 person who signed the application:
10 (a) Failed to report any required information to the Department
11 that the person knew at the time the person signed the application;
12 (b) Refused to provide financial information regarding the
13 recipient’s income and assets, including, without limitation,
14 information regarding any transfers or assignments of income or
15 assets;
16 (c) Concealed information regarding the existence, transfer or
17 disposition of the recipient’s income and assets with the intent of
18 enabling a recipient to meet any eligibility requirement for public
19 assistance;
20 (d) Made any false representation regarding the recipient’s
21 income and assets, including, without limitation, any information
22 regarding any transfers or assignments of income or assets; or
23 (e) Failed to report to the Department within the period allowed
24 by the Department any required information that the person obtained
25 after the person filed the application.
26 2. Except as otherwise provided in this section, a recipient of
27 incorrectly paid public assistance or a person who signed the
28 application for public benefits on behalf of the recipient shall
29 reimburse the Department or appropriate state agency for the value
30 of the incorrectly paid public assistance.
31 3. The Director or a person designated by the Director may, to
32 the extent that it is not prohibited by federal law, determine the
33 amount of, and settle, adjust, compromise or deny a claim against a
34 recipient of public assistance, the estate of the recipient or a person
35 who signed the application for public assistance on behalf of the
36 recipient.
37 4. The Director may, to the extent that it is not prohibited by
38 federal law, waive the repayment of public assistance incorrectly
39 paid to a recipient if the incorrect payment was not the result of an
40 intentional misrepresentation or omission by the recipient and if
41 repayment would cause an undue hardship to the recipient. The
42 Director shall, by regulation, establish the terms and conditions of
43 such a waiver, including, without limitation, the circumstances that
44 constitute undue hardship.

35 Sec. 169. NRS 439.873 is hereby amended to read as follows:
36 439.873 1. A medical facility shall designate an officer or

38 the medical facility.
39 2. The person who is designated as the infection control officer
40 of a medical facility:
41 (a) Shall serve on the patient safety committee.
42 (b) Shall monitor the occurrences of infections at the medical
43 facility to determine the number and severity of infections.
44 (c) Shall report to the patient safety committee concerning the
45 number and severity of infections at the medical facility.
-
*SB494*
– 140 –
1 (d) Shall take such action as he or she determines is necessary to
2 prevent and control infections alleged to have occurred at the
3 medical facility.
4 (e) Shall carry out the provisions of the infection control
5 program adopted pursuant to NRS 439.865 and ensure compliance
6 with the program.
7 3. If a medical facility has 175 or more beds, the person who is
8 designated as the infection control officer of the medical facility
9 must be certified as an infection preventionist by the Certification
10 Board of Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc., or a successor
11 organization. A person may serve as the certified infection
12 preventionist for more than one medical facility if the facilities have
13 common ownership.
14 4. A medical facility that designates an infection control officer
15 who is not a certified infection preventionist must ensure that the
16 person has successfully completed a nationally recognized basic
17 training program in infection control, which may include, without
18 limitation, the program offered by the Association for Professionals
19 in Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc., or a successor
20 organization. A medical facility shall ensure that an infection
21 control officer completes at least 4 hours of continuing education
22 each year on topics relating to current practices in infection control
23 and prevention.
24 5. A medical facility shall ensure that it maintains a ratio of at

26 for every 100 occupied beds. The number of beds must be
27 determined based upon the most recent annual calendar-year
28 average reported by the medical facility to the Director of the

30 pursuant thereto.

6 any recommendations for legislation, regulations or other changes to
7 policy or budgets to address those issues.
8 (b) Submit the report to the Governor and the Director of the
9 Legislative Counsel Bureau for transmittal to:
10 (1) In January of odd-numbered years, the next regular
11 session of the Legislature.
12 (2) In all other cases, to the Joint Interim Standing
13 Committee on Health and Human Services.
14 3. Upon receiving a report pursuant to subsection 2, the
15 Governor shall post the report on an Internet website maintained by
16 the Governor.
17 4. The Commission may prepare and publish additional reports
18 on specific topics at the direction of the Chair.

31 3. In reviewing an application for approval, the Director shall:
32 (a) Comparatively assess applications for similar projects
33 affecting the same geographic area; and

36 (1) The need for and the appropriateness of the project in the
37 area to be served;
38 (2) The financial feasibility of the project;
39 (3) The effect of the project on the cost of health care; and
40 (4) The extent to which the project is consistent with the

43 (I) The impact of the project on other health care

-
*SB494*
– 150 –
1 (II) The need for any equipment that the project proposes
2 to add, the manner in which such equipment will improve the
3 quality of health care and any protocols provided in the project for
4 avoiding repetitive testing;
5 (III) The impact of the project on disparate health
6 outcomes for different populations in the area that will be served by
7 the project;
8 (IV) The manner in which the project will expand,
9 promote or enhance the capacity to provide primary health care in
10 the area that will be served by the project;
11 (V) Any plan by the applicant to collect and analyze data
12 concerning the effect of the project on health care quality and
13 patient outcomes in the area served by the project;
14 (VI) Any plan by the applicant for controlling the spread
15 of infectious diseases; and
16 (VII) The manner in which the applicant will coordinate
17 with and support existing health facilities and practitioners,
18 including, without limitation, mental health facilities, programs for
19 the treatment and prevention of substance use disorders and
20 providers of nursing services.

27 purposes of judicial review.

6 3. A physician, hospital or other health facility which treats a
7 patient as a result of a violation of subsection 2 by a hospital or a
8 physician working in the hospital is entitled to recover from that
9 hospital an amount equal to three times the charges for the treatment
10 provided that was billed by the physician, hospital or other health
11 facility which provided the treatment, plus reasonable attorney’s
12 fees and costs.
13 4. This section does not prohibit the transfer of a patient from
14 one hospital to another:
15 (a) When the patient is covered by an insurance policy or other
16 contractual arrangement which provides for payment at the
17 receiving hospital;
18 (b) After the county responsible for payment for the care of an
19 indigent patient has exhausted the money which may be
20 appropriated for that purpose pursuant to NRS 428.050, 428.285 and
21 450.425; or
22 (c) When the hospital cannot provide the services needed by the
23 patient.
24  No transfer may be made pursuant to this subsection until the
25 patient’s condition has been stabilized to a degree that allows the
26 transfer without an additional risk to the patient.
27 5. As used in this section:
28 (a) “Emergency services and care” means medical screening,
29 examination and evaluation by a physician or, to the extent
30 permitted by a specific statute, by a person under the supervision of
31 a physician, to determine if an emergency medical condition or
32 active labor exists and, if it does, the care, treatment and surgery by
33 a physician necessary to relieve or eliminate the emergency medical
34 condition or active labor, within the capability of the hospital. As
35 used in this paragraph:
36 (1) “Active labor” means, in relation to childbirth, labor that
37 occurs when:
38 (I) There is inadequate time before delivery to transfer the
39 patient safely to another hospital; or
40 (II) A transfer may pose a threat to the health and safety
41 of the patient or the unborn child.
42 (2) “Emergency medical condition” means the presence of
43 acute symptoms of sufficient severity, including severe pain, such
44 that the absence of immediate medical attention could reasonably be
45 expected to result in:
-
*SB494*
– 162 –
1 (I) Placing the health of the patient in serious jeopardy;
2 (II) Serious impairment of bodily functions; or
3 (III) Serious dysfunction of any bodily organ or part.
4 (b) “Medically fit” means that the condition of the patient has
5 been sufficiently stabilized so that the patient may be safely
6 transported to another hospital, or is such that, in the determination
7 of the attending physician, the transfer of the patient constitutes an
8 acceptable risk. Such a determination must be based upon the
9 condition of the patient, the expected benefits, if any, to the patient
10 resulting from the transfer and whether the risks to the patient’s
11 health are outweighed by the expected benefits, and must be
12 documented in the patient’s records before the transfer.
13 6. If an allegation of a violation of the provisions of subsection
14 2 is made against a hospital licensed pursuant to the provisions of
15 chapter 449 of NRS, the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance
16 Division of [Public and Behavioral Health of the Department] the
17 Authority shall conduct an investigation of the alleged violation.
18 Such a violation, in addition to any criminal penalties that may be
19 imposed, constitutes grounds for the denial, suspension or
20 revocation of such a license, or for the imposition of any sanction
21 prescribed by NRS 449.163.
22 7. If an allegation of a violation of the provisions of subsection
23 2 is made against:
24 (a) A physician licensed to practice medicine pursuant to the
25 provisions of chapter 630 of NRS, the Board of Medical Examiners
26 shall conduct an investigation of the alleged violation. Such a
27 violation, in addition to any criminal penalties that may be imposed,
28 constitutes grounds for initiating disciplinary action or denying
29 licensure pursuant to the provisions of subsection 3 of
30 NRS 630.3065.
31 (b) An osteopathic physician licensed to practice osteopathic
32 medicine pursuant to the provisions of chapter 633 of NRS, the
33 State Board of Osteopathic Medicine shall conduct an investigation
34 of the alleged violation. Such a violation, in addition to any criminal
35 penalties that may be imposed, constitutes grounds for initiating
36 disciplinary action pursuant to the provisions of subsection 1 of
37 NRS 633.131.

8 assistant.
9 5. The Board shall report any failure to comply with subsection
10 3 or 4 by a hospital, clinic or other medical facility licensed in this
11 State to the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division of
12 [Public and Behavioral Health of the Department of Health and
13 Human Services.] the Nevada Health Authority. If, after a hearing,
14 the Division determines that any such facility or society failed to
15 comply with the requirements of subsection 3 or 4, the Division may
16 impose an administrative fine of not more than $10,000 against the
17 facility or society for each such failure to report. If the
18 administrative fine is not paid when due, the fine must be recovered
19 in a civil action brought by the Attorney General on behalf of the
20 Division.
21 6. The clerk of every court shall report to the Board any
22 finding, judgment or other determination of the court that an
23 osteopathic physician, physician assistant or anesthesiologist
24 assistant:
25 (a) Is mentally ill;
26 (b) Is mentally incompetent;
27 (c) Has been convicted of a felony or any law governing
28 controlled substances or dangerous drugs;
29 (d) Is guilty of abuse or fraud under any state or federal program
30 providing medical assistance; or
31 (e) Is liable for damages for malpractice or negligence,
32  within 45 days after the finding, judgment or determination.

28 patient in the facility. The sealed container must be stored at all
29 times in a locked compartment on the premises of the facility.
30 3. All drugs delivered to a facility must be signed for by the
31 nurse or other person in charge. An inventory of the stock of drugs
32 must be appended to the sealed container. Immediately after the
33 drugs are needed, the physician or registered nurse who breaks the
34 seal shall enter on the inventory sheet the following information:
35 (a) The date and time the sealed container is opened;
36 (b) The name of the patient for whom the drugs are to be used;
37 (c) The name of the patient’s physician or the physician who
38 directs the administration of the drugs, if different;
39 (d) An itemization of the drugs removed; and
40 (e) The signature of the person who opened the sealed container.

42 required by subsection 3 has been entered on the inventory, the
43 physician or registered nurse shall immediately replace the container
44 in a locked compartment and shall notify the pharmaceutical
-
*SB494*
– 215 –
1 consultant, as soon as it is practical to do so, that the container has

3 5. The sealed container and its contents at all times remain the

6 day if notification is not received during business hours, but in no
7 event more than 48 hours following receipt of the notification, the
8 pharmaceutical consultant shall:
9 (a) Examine the inventory sheet;
10 (b) Replace the drugs removed;
11 (c) Secure a written prescription for the drugs replaced, if one is
12 required by law;
13 (d) Enter the name and quantity of the drugs so replaced on the
14 inventory sheet, together with the date and time of replacement;
15 (e) Reseal the container; and
16 (f) Sign the inventory sheet.
17 6. No person other than a licensed physician or registered nurse

26 licensing board, the Board shall refer the complaint to the other
27 licensing board within 5 days after making the determination.
28 2. The Board may refer a complaint pursuant to subsection 1
29 orally, electronically or in writing.
30 3. The provisions of subsection 1 apply to any complaint filed
31 with the Board, including, without limitation:
32 (a) A complaint which concerns a person who or entity which is
33 licensed, certified or otherwise regulated by the Board or by another
34 licensing board; and
35 (b) A complaint which concerns a person who or entity which is
36 licensed, certified or otherwise regulated solely by another licensing
37 board.
38 4. The provisions of this section do not prevent the Board from
39 acting upon a complaint which concerns a matter within the
40 jurisdiction of the Board regardless of whether the Board refers the
41 complaint pursuant to subsection 1.
42 5. The Board or an officer or employee of the Board is immune
43 from any civil liability for any decision or action taken in good faith
44 and without malicious intent in carrying out the provisions in this
45 section.

Raw Text:
EXEMPT
S.B. 494
SENATE BILL NO. 494–COMMITTEE ON FINANCE
(ON BEHALF OF THE OFFICE OF FINANCE
IN THE OFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR)
MAY 15, 2025
____________
Referred to Committee on Health and Human Services
SUMMARY—Makes revisions relating to health and human
services. (BDR 18-1116)
FISCAL NOTE: Effect on Local Government: May have Fiscal Impact.
Effect on the State: Executive Budget.
~
EXPLANATION – Matter in bolded italics is new; matter between brackets [omitted material] is material to be omitted.
AN ACT relating to state government; creating the Nevada Health
Authority; creating certain divisions and offices within
the Authority; providing for the appointment of officers
and the employment of staff for the Authority;
establishing requirements governing procurement by the
Authority; creating the Nevada Health Authority Gift
Fund; prescribing the duties of the Authority and its
divisions and officers; transferring to the Authority the
responsibility for operating various programs and
administering various provisions; revising the name of
certain agencies; revising certain terminology; eliminating
the Division of Health Care Financing and Policy of the
Department of Health and Human Services; revising
provisions governing the operation of the Public
Employees’ Benefits Program; revising the membership
and duties of the Board of Directors of the Silver State
Health Insurance Exchange; and providing other matters
properly relating thereto.
Legislative Counsel’s Digest:
1 Existing law creates the Department of Health and Human Services, which
2 consists of the Aging and Disability Services Division, the Division of Public and
3 Behavioral Health, the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services, the Division
4 of Child and Family Services and the Division of Health Care Financing and
5 Policy. (NRS 232.300) This bill creates a new department within the Executive
-
*SB494*

– 2 –
6 Department of the State Government known as the Nevada Health Authority to
7 assume certain responsibilities of the Department of Health and Human Services
8 and other entities related to the management of certain public health insurance
9 plans, the licensing and regulation of certain persons and entities involved in the
10 provision of health care and the regulation of sanitation in food establishments and
11 certain other locations.
12 Section 18 of this bill creates and establishes the purposes of the Authority, and
13 section 32 of this bill changes the name of the Department to the Department of
14 Human Services. Section 18 provides that the Authority consists of: (1) the
15 Medicaid Division; (2) the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division; and
16 (3) the Consumer Health Division. Section 19 of this bill requires the Governor to
17 appoint a Director of the Authority who possesses certain qualifications. Sections
18 20-23 and 29 of this bill provide for the appointment of officers and the
19 employment of staff for the Authority, including an administrator of each division
20 of the Authority. Sections 24 and 79 of this bill exempt the Authority from
21 provisions of law governing state procurement, with certain exceptions, and section
22 24 prescribes requirements governing procurement by the Authority. Sections 24
23 and 61 of this bill provide for the confidentiality of certain information submitted
24 to the Authority during the procurement process. Section 25 of this bill authorizes:
25 (1) the sharing of confidential information within the Authority; and (2) the
26 Authority to share confidential information with certain agencies of local
27 governments in certain circumstances. Sections 26 and 34 of this bill transfer from
28 the Department to the Authority the authority to administer certain programs for
29 persons with developmental disabilities. Section 28 of this bill requires the Director
30 or the Director’s designee to adopt each state plan required by the Federal
31 Government for the administration of any program for which the Authority or a
32 division thereof is responsible. Section 31 of this bill creates the Nevada Health
33 Authority Gift Fund to hold gifts, grants and other property which the Authority is
34 authorized to accept. Sections 113 and 227 of this bill require the deposit of certain
35 money in the Fund. Section 36 of this bill updates the name of the Department of
36 Health and Human Services Gift Fund, which is created by existing law, to conform
37 to the change in the name of the Department. (NRS 232.355)
38 Existing law requires the Office of Science, Innovation and Technology in the
39 Office of the Governor to administer the Graduate Medical Education Grant
40 Program, which is a program to award grants to institutions in this State seeking to
41 create, expand or retain programs for residency training and postdoctoral
42 fellowships for physicians. (NRS 223.631-223.639) Sections 2-8 and 26 of this bill
43 transfer to the Consumer Health Division the responsibility for administering the
44 Program.
45 Existing law requires the Board of the Public Employees’ Benefits Program to
46 establish the Program to provide group life, accident or health insurance, or any
47 combination thereof, to employees of the State Government. (NRS 287.043)
48 Section 68 of this bill places the Board within the Authority and makes revisions
49 governing the appointment of the members of the Board. Section 69 of this bill
50 transfers from the Board to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for
51 appointing the Executive Officer of the Program. Section 70 of this bill requires the
52 Executive Officer to submit to the Authority a report regarding the administration
53 and operation of the Program, in addition to certain other entities that currently
54 receive the report. Section 71 of this bill provides that the appointment of officers
55 and unclassified employees to administer the Program is subject to the approval of
56 the Director of the Authority. Sections 72-74 of this bill authorize the Board to
57 utilize certain services of the Authority, including procurement services.
58 Existing law requires: (1) the Department to administer Medicaid and the
59 Children’s Health Insurance Program; and (2) the Division of Health Care
60 Financing and Policy of the Department to perform certain duties related to the
-
*SB494*

– 3 –
61 administration of those programs. (Chapter 422 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 93-96,
62 113-117 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department and the Director of the
63 Department to the Medicaid Division and the Director of the Authority the
64 responsibility for administering Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance
65 Program. Sections 32, 34 and 35 of this bill abolish the Division of Health Care
66 Financing and Policy, and sections 94 and 359 transfer the authority, duties and
67 responsibilities of that Division to the Medicaid Division. Section 86 of this bill
68 authorizes the Authority to delegate to other governmental entities the
69 responsibility for making determinations of eligibility for Medicaid and the
70 Children’s Health Insurance Program. Section 87 of this bill creates the Office of
71 the Medicaid Inspector General within the Authority to perform certain duties to
72 ensure the integrity of Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program and
73 to prevent waste, fraud and abuse in those programs. Sections 66, 88-91 and 371 of
74 this bill transfer or provide to the Authority certain responsibilities related to the
75 administration of those programs. Sections 101-104, 109 and 110 of this bill
76 establish provisions governing the qualifications, supervision and activities of the
77 Administrator of the Medicaid Division, which are similar to the qualifications,
78 supervision and activities of the Administrator of the Division of Health Care
79 Financing and Policy. (NRS 422.2354-422.2364, 422.2372) Sections 105-108, 111
80 and 112 of this bill transfer to the Director certain responsibilities relating to
81 Medicaid and the Children’s Health Insurance Program, including the responsibility
82 for adopting regulations governing those programs. Section 116 requires any
83 contract for the expenditure of federal money under Medicaid to be signed by the
84 Director. Section 118 of this bill requires the Authority to: (1) include on an
85 Internet website maintained by the Authority certain information to allow recipients
86 of Medicaid through managed care to compare available plans; and (2) develop and
87 implement a beneficiary support system for such recipients of Medicaid. Section
88 371 repeals certain fiscal duties previously performed by the Administrator of the
89 Division of Health Care Financing and Policy.
90 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144-146, 194, 217-224, 245-247, 250, 260, 276, 325-327
91 and 360 of this bill transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to
92 the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division and from the Department of
93 Health and Human Services to the Nevada Health Authority, as applicable, the
94 responsibilities for credentialing and regulating: (1) programs for the treatment of
95 persons who commit domestic violence; (2) health care facilities and certain entities
96 involved in the provision of personal care services; (3) nontransplant anatomical
97 donation organizations; (4) naprapaths; and (5) medical laboratories and their
98 personnel. Section 143 of this bill authorizes the State Board of Health to establish
99 fees for the credentialing functions and certain other functions of the Health Care
100 Purchasing and Compliance Division. Sections 26, 34 and 162-171 of this bill
101 transfer from the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to the Health Care
102 Purchasing and Compliance Division the responsibility for administering
103 provisions governing health and safety at health care facilities, including the
104 reporting of sentinel events. Section 35 reduces the number of deputy
105 administrators in the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to account for the
106 duties removed from that Division.
107 Sections 26, 34, 141, 144, 145, 147-152, 154-160, 180-187, 197-200, 226-238,
108 240-244 and 359 of this bill transfer from the Department to the Authority the
109 responsibility for administering; (1) the State Program for Oral Health; (2)
110 provisions governing health information technology; (3) the programs to increase
111 public awareness of health care information concerning hospitals and surgical
112 centers for ambulatory patients in this State; (4) provisions governing the reporting
113 of information relating to the cost of certain prescription drugs and certain
114 information concerning pharmacies; (5) the Nevada Health Facilities Assistance
115 Act, which establishes a program to construct new health facilities in this State; and
-
*SB494*

– 4 –
116 (6) certain requirements to ensure the quality of care offered by hospitals in this
117 State and the financial stability of such hospitals.
118 Existing law: (1) creates the Patient Protection Commission within the Office
119 of the Director of the Department; and (2) requires the Commission to perform
120 certain duties to improve the quality, accessibility and affordability of health care in
121 this State. (NRS 439.908, 439.918) Sections 26, 34, 172 and 173 of this bill
122 transfer the Commission to the Consumer Health Division. Section 173 also
123 transfers from the Governor to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for
124 appointing the members of the Commission. Sections 174 and 175 of this bill
125 require the Commission to make certain recommendations and submit certain
126 reports to the Director of the Authority.
127 Existing law requires the Department to establish an all-payer claims database
128 of information relating to health insurance claims resulting from medical, dental or
129 pharmacy benefits provided in this State. (NRS 439B.835) Section 29 creates the
130 Office of Data Analytics within the Authority, and sections 26, 34, 202-204 and
131 359 of this bill transfer to the Office the responsibility for operating the all-payer
132 claims database.
133 Existing law: (1) requires the Division of Public and Behavioral Health to
134 enforce provisions governing sanitation and food establishments under certain
135 circumstances; and (2) requires each county where the Division provides such
136 enforcement to pay an assessment to the Division. (NRS 439.4905, chapters 444
137 and 446 of NRS) Sections 26, 34, 206-208 and 210-216 of this bill transfer to the
138 Authority the authority to enforce provisions governing sanitation and food
139 establishments, and sections 30 and 153 of this bill require counties who currently
140 pay to the Division an assessment for those functions to instead pay the assessment
141 to the Authority.
142 Existing law requires the State Board of Health to license and regulate music
143 therapists and dietitians. (Chapters 640D and 640E of NRS) Sections 26, 283-297
144 and 300-323 of this bill transfer to the Health Care Purchasing and Compliance
145 Division the responsibilities for issuing and renewing licenses to those
146 professionals and enforcing provisions of law and regulations governing
147 those professionals and leave the authority to adopt regulations governing those
148 professions with the State Board.
149 Existing law creates the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange. (NRS
150 695I.200) Existing law requires the Exchange to: (1) create and administer a state-
151 based health insurance exchange; (2) facilitate the purchase and sale of qualified
152 health plans; (3) provide for the establishment of a program to help certain small
153 employers in Nevada in facilitating the enrollment of employees in qualified health
154 plans; and (4) perform all other duties required pursuant to the federal Patient
155 Protection and Affordable Care Act, the federal Health Care and Education
156 Reconciliation Act of 2010 and any amendments to or regulations or guidance
157 issued pursuant to those Acts. (Pub. L. No. 111-148, Pub. L. No. 111-152; NRS
158 695I.200, 695I.210) The Exchange is governed by the Board of Directors
159 consisting of five voting members appointed by the Governor, one voting member
160 appointed by the Senate Majority Leader, one voting member appointed by the
161 Speaker of the Assembly and three ex officio, nonvoting members. (NRS 695I.300)
162 Sections 346-348 of this bill place the Exchange under the authority of the
163 Consumer Health Division. Section 348: (1) reduces the number of members of the
164 Board appointed by the Governor from five to two; (2) adds three heads of agencies
165 whose work relates to public health or health insurance as ex officio, voting
166 members of the Board; and (3) reduces the nonvoting membership of the Board.
167 Sections 349 and 350 of this bill make revisions governing the terms of the
168 members and officers of the Board. Section 352 of this bill transfers from
169 the Board to the Director of the Authority the responsibility for appointing the
170 Executive Director of the Exchange. Sections 351 and 352 of this bill transfer
-
*SB494*

– 5 –
171 certain duties relating to auditing and reports from the Board to the Executive
172 Director. Sections 353 and 354 of this bill transfer certain other duties related to
173 the Exchange to Authority and its Director.
174 Existing law requires the Director of the Department, in consultation with the
175 Commissioner of Insurance and the Executive Director of the Exchange, to design,
176 establish and operate a health benefit plan known as the Public Option. (NRS
177 695K.200) Section 355 of this bill transfers the responsibility for designing,
178 establishing and operating the Public Option to the Director of the Authority.
179 Section 27 of this bill requires the Director and the Authority to take certain
180 actions to facilitate determinations of eligibility for and the selection of plans under
181 Medicaid and certain other public health insurance programs under the jurisdiction
182 of the Authority. Sections 9-13, 38-60, 62, 77, 78, 80, 81, 83, 96-98, 100, 121, 123,
183 125, 128-139, 142, 161, 178, 179, 188, 189, 195, 196, 205, 209, 248, 249, 251-275,
184 277-280, 324, 328-336, 338-341 and 356-358 of this bill make various conforming
185 changes to reflect the authority transferred by the provisions of this bill. Sections
186 32, 34, 38, 46, 99, 122, 127, 239, 287, 307 and 326 of this bill change the name of
187 the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services of the Department to the Division
188 of Social Services of the Department. Sections 33, 37, 82, 119, 120, 123, 124, 126-
189 128 and 368 of this bill revise the terminology to refer to certain programs operated
190 by that Division from “welfare” to “public assistance.” Section 132 revises the term
191 “transitional assistance” to “child care assistance” to describe certain assistance
192 provided pursuant to federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program.
193 Sections 1, 16, 17, 64, 65, 85, 140, 176, 191, 192, 225, 240, 281, 298, 343 and 344
194 of this bill define certain terms, and sections 15, 67, 75, 76, 92, 177, 193, 201, 282,
195 299, 337 and 345 of this bill make conforming changes to indicate the applicability
196 of those definitions. Section 371 eliminates certain definitions that are no longer
197 necessary.
198 Section 361 of this bill transfers to the Authority the duty to carry out any
199 requirements of a bill that is enacted by the Legislature during this session and
200 approved by the Governor to: (1) require the Department of Health and Human
201 Services to operate a program to award money to support projects to address
202 shortages of providers of health care in this State; or (2) impose certain
203 requirements on Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

34 Sec. 16. “Authority” means the Nevada Health Authority.
35 Sec. 17. “Director” means the Director of the Authority.
36 Sec. 18. 1. The Nevada Health Authority is hereby created
37 as a department within the Executive Department of the State
38 Government.
39 2. The purposes of the Authority are to:
40 (a) Improve access to health care that is safe, of high quality
41 and affordable;
42 (b) Promote the development of a workforce of providers of
43 health care that is sufficient to meet the demand for health care in
44 this State;
-
*SB494*

– 17 –
1 (c) Ensure the availability of affordable health coverage for
2 residents of this State, including, without limitation, current and
3 retired employees of the State Government;
4 (d) Develop effective and efficient systems for delivering health
5 care and value-based strategies for procuring health insurance
6 coverage in the most sustainable and responsive manner possible;
7 and
8 (e) Ensure the long-term stability of Medicaid, the Children’s
9 Health Insurance Program, the Public Employees’ Benefits
10 Program, the Silver State Health Insurance Exchange and the
11 Public Option by minimizing the financial burden of health care
12 on persons who receive health coverage through those programs,
13 the state budget and other residents of this State through the use
14 of measures to contain costs, maximizing the impact of state and
15 federal money and the application of innovative purchasing and
16 contracting strategies.
17 3. The Authority consists of a Director and:
18 (a) The Medicaid Division;
19 (b) The Health Care Purchasing and Compliance Division;
20 and
21 (c) The Consumer Health Division.
22 4. The Authority is the sole agency responsible for
23 administering the provisions of law relating to its respective
24 divisions.
25 Sec. 19. The Director:
26 1. Is appointed by, is responsible to, and serves at the
27 pleasure of the Governor.
28 2. Is in the unclassified service of the State.
29 3. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 284.143, shall not
30 engage in any other gainful employment or occupation.
31 4. Must have broad, responsible experience in the field of
32 administration or possess broad management skills or working
33 knowledge of the field of health care or public health
34 administration.
35 5. Must be selected with special reference to his or her
36 training, experience and aptitude for coordinating related
37 functions of public health agencies and public health insurance
38 programs. The Director’s knowledge and abilities should include
39 the following:
40 (a) A comprehensive knowledge of administrative principles,
41 and a working knowledge of principles of public finance and the
42 laws, rules and regulations pertaining to public agencies.
43 (b) Administrative ability to assess the operating efficiency of
44 component agencies and to delegate authority and duties to
45 responsible deputy directors or other personnel of the Authority.
-
*SB494*

– 18 –
1 (c) The ability to organize and clearly present oral and written
2 findings and recommendations to the Governor, the Legislature
3 and other officials and agencies.
4 Sec. 20. 1. The Director may employ, within the limits of
5 legislative appropriations, such staff as is necessary to the
6 performance of the Director’s duties.
7 2. Any provider of health care who is employed by the
8 Authority for purposes related to Medicaid or the Children’s
9 Health Insurance Program must sign a form agreeing to:
10 (a) Avoid or minimize conflicts of interest between the
11 personal interests of the provider of health care and the interests
12 of Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program; and
13 (b) If a conflict of interest described in paragraph (a) arises:
14 (1) Report the conflict to the Administrator of the Medicaid
15 Division of the Authority; and
16 (2) Recuse himself or herself from action or deliberation on
17 the matter in the capacity of his or her employment with the
18 Authority.
19 3. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Director,
20 or the Director’s designee, is responsible for appointing and
21 removing subordinate officers and employees of the Authority.
22 Sec. 21. 1. The Director shall appoint, with the consent of
23 the Governor, the following Deputy Directors:

25 operations of the Authority, including, without limitation, human
26 resources, the training and development of staff and the

26 Sec. 31. 1. Except for gifts or grants specifically accounted
27 for in another fund, all gifts or grants of money or other property
28 which the divisions of the Authority are authorized to accept must
29 be accounted for in the Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund,
30 which is hereby created as a special revenue fund. The Fund is a
31 continuing fund without reversion. The Authority may establish
32 such accounts in the Fund as are necessary to account properly
33 for gifts received. All such money received by the divisions of the
34 Authority must be deposited in the State Treasury for credit to the
35 Fund. The money in the Fund must be paid out on claims as other
36 claims against the State are paid. Unless otherwise specifically
37 provided by statute, claims against the Fund must be approved by
38 the Director or the Director’s delegate.
39 2. Gifts of property other than money may be sold or
40 exchanged when this is deemed by the head of the agency
41 responsible for the gift to be in the best interest of the agency. The
42 sale price must not be less than 90 percent of the value determined
43 by a qualified appraiser appointed by the head of the agency. All
44 money received from the sale must be deposited in the State
45 Treasury to the credit of the appropriate gift account in the
-
*SB494*

– 27 –
1 Nevada Health Authority Gift Fund. The money may be spent only
2 for the purposes of the agency named in the title of the account.
3 The property may not be sold or exchanged if doing so would
4 violate the terms of the gift.

1 Sec. 44. NRS 111.779 is hereby amended to read as follows:
2 111.779 1. Except as otherwise provided in NRS 21.090 and
3 other applicable law, a transferee of a nonprobate transfer is liable to
4 the probate estate of the decedent for allowed claims against that
5 decedent’s probate estate to the extent the estate is insufficient to
6 satisfy those claims.
7 2. The liability of a nonprobate transferee may not exceed the
8 value of nonprobate transfers received or controlled by that
9 transferee.
10 3. Nonprobate transferees are liable for the insufficiency
11 described in subsection 1 in the following order of priority:
12 (a) A transferee specified in the decedent’s will or any other
13 governing instrument as being liable for such an insufficiency, in the
14 order of priority provided in the will or other governing instrument;
15 (b) The trustee of a trust serving as the principal nonprobate
16 instrument in the decedent’s estate plan as shown by its designation

18 circumstances, to the extent of the value of the nonprobate transfer
19 received or controlled; and
20 (c) Other nonprobate transferees, in proportion to the values
21 received.

42 petitioner; and

44 evidence known to the petitioner that tends to prove that the will is
45 valid.

– 53 –
1 9. If the petition seeks to have the estate set aside for the
