9 3. Each agency, after reducing a report to writing, shall forward
10 a copy of the report to the Aging and Disability Services Division of
11 the Department of [Health and] Human Services and the Unit for the
12 Investigation and Prosecution of Crimes.
13 4. A report must be made pursuant to subsection 1 by the
14 following persons:
15 (a) Every physician, dentist, dental hygienist, expanded function
16 dental assistant, chiropractic physician, naprapath, optometrist,
17 podiatric physician, medical examiner, resident, intern, professional
18 or practical nurse, physician assistant licensed pursuant to chapter
19 630 or 633 of NRS, anesthesiologist assistant, perfusionist,
20 psychiatrist, psychologist, marriage and family therapist, clinical
21 professional counselor, clinical alcohol and drug counselor, alcohol
22 and drug counselor, music therapist, athletic trainer, driver of an
23 ambulance, paramedic, licensed dietitian, holder of a license or a
24 limited license issued under the provisions of chapter 653 of NRS,
25 behavior analyst, assistant behavior analyst, registered behavior
26 technician, peer recovery support specialist, as defined in NRS
27 433.627, peer recovery support specialist supervisor, as defined in
28 NRS 433.629, or other person providing medical services licensed
29 or certified to practice in this State, who examines, attends or treats
30 an older person or vulnerable person who appears to have been
31 abused, neglected, exploited, isolated or abandoned.
32 (b) Any personnel of a hospital or similar institution engaged in
33 the admission, examination, care or treatment of persons or an
34 administrator, manager or other person in charge of a hospital or
35 similar institution upon notification of the suspected abuse, neglect,
36 exploitation, isolation or abandonment of an older person or
37 vulnerable person by a member of the staff of the hospital.
38 (c) A coroner.
39 (d) Every person who maintains or is employed by an agency to
40 provide personal care services in the home.
41 (e) Every person who maintains or is employed by an agency to
42 provide nursing in the home.
43 (f) Every person who operates, who is employed by or who
44 contracts to provide services for an intermediary service
45 organization as defined in NRS 449.4304.
-
*SB494*

– 66 –
1 (g) Any employee of the Department of [Health and] Human
2 Services, except the State Long-Term Care Ombudsman appointed
3 pursuant to NRS 427A.125 and any of his or her advocates or
4 volunteers where prohibited from making such a report pursuant to
5 45 C.F.R. § 1321.11.
6 (h) Any employee of a law enforcement agency or a county’s
7 office for protective services or an adult or juvenile probation
8 officer.
9 (i) Any person who maintains or is employed by a facility or
10 establishment that provides care for older persons or vulnerable
11 persons.

13 volunteer for an agency or service which advises persons regarding
14 the abuse, neglect, exploitation, isolation or abandonment of an
15 older person or vulnerable person and refers them to persons and
16 agencies where their requests and needs can be met.
17 (k) Every social worker.
18 (l) Any person who owns or is employed by a funeral home or

25 Health Care Financing and Policy] of the [Department of Health and

28 5. A report may be made by any other person.
29 6. If a person who is required to make a report pursuant to
30 subsection 1 knows or has reasonable cause to believe that an older
31 person or vulnerable person has died as a result of abuse, neglect,
32 isolation or abandonment, the person shall, as soon as reasonably

36 enforcement agencies, the appropriate prosecuting attorney, the
37 Aging and Disability Services Division of the Department of
38 [Health and] Human Services and the Unit for the Investigation and
39 Prosecution of Crimes his or her written findings. The written
40 findings must include the information required pursuant to the
41 provisions of NRS 200.5094, when possible.

45 investigation conducted by a division, office or department, other

14 711.600, and section 24 of this act, sections 35, 38 and 41 of
15 chapter 478, Statutes of Nevada 2011 and section 2 of chapter 391,
16 Statutes of Nevada 2013 and unless otherwise declared by law to be
17 confidential, all public books and public records of a governmental
18 entity must be open at all times during office hours to inspection by
19 any person, and may be fully copied or an abstract or memorandum
20 may be prepared from those public books and public records. Any
21 such copies, abstracts or memoranda may be used to supply the
22 general public with copies, abstracts or memoranda of the records or
23 may be used in any other way to the advantage of the governmental
24 entity or of the general public. This section does not supersede or in
25 any manner affect the federal laws governing copyrights or enlarge,
26 diminish or affect in any other manner the rights of a person in any
27 written book or record which is copyrighted pursuant to federal law.
28 2. A governmental entity may not reject a book or record
29 which is copyrighted solely because it is copyrighted.
30 3. A governmental entity that has legal custody or control of a
31 public book or record shall not deny a request made pursuant to
32 subsection 1 to inspect or copy or receive a copy of a public book or
33 record on the basis that the requested public book or record contains
34 information that is confidential if the governmental entity can
35 redact, delete, conceal or separate, including, without limitation,
36 electronically, the confidential information from the information
37 included in the public book or record that is not otherwise
38 confidential.
39 4. If requested, a governmental entity shall provide a copy of a
40 public record in an electronic format by means of an electronic
41 medium. Nothing in this subsection requires a governmental entity
42 to provide a copy of a public record in an electronic format or by
43 means of an electronic medium if:
44 (a) The public record:
45 (1) Was not created or prepared in an electronic format; and
-
*SB494*

– 72 –
1 (2) Is not available in an electronic format; or
2 (b) Providing the public record in an electronic format or by
3 means of an electronic medium would:
4 (1) Give access to proprietary software; or
5 (2) Require the production of information that is confidential
6 and that cannot be redacted, deleted, concealed or separated from
7 information that is not otherwise confidential.
8 5. An officer, employee or agent of a governmental entity who
9 has legal custody or control of a public record:
10 (a) Shall not refuse to provide a copy of that public record in the
11 medium that is requested because the officer, employee or agent has
12 already prepared or would prefer to provide the copy in a different
13 medium.
14 (b) Except as otherwise provided in NRS 239.030, shall, upon
15 request, prepare the copy of the public record and shall not require
16 the person who has requested the copy to prepare the copy himself
17 or herself.

21 or local governmental agency to which the Authority has
22 delegated a function; and

24 or local governmental agency to which the Authority has
25 delegated a function.

27 pursuant to subsection 1 shall comply with the relevant provisions
28 of this chapter to the same extent as the Authority.

30 provide reimbursements to an entity to which the Authority has
31 delegated functions pursuant to this section if the Authority has
32 entered into an agreement with the entity that entitles the
33 Authority to sufficient information to conduct regular audits of

19 6. A majority of the members of the Advisory Committee
20 constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business, and a majority
21 of a quorum present at any meeting is sufficient for any official
22 action taken by the Advisory Committee.
23 7. The Advisory Committee shall:
24 (a) At its first meeting and annually thereafter, elect a Chair
25 from among its members;
26 (b) Meet at the call of the Director [,] of the Authority, the Chair
27 or a majority of its members as necessary and within the budget of
28 the Advisory Committee; and
29 (c) On or before July 1 of each year, submit a written report to
30 the Director of the Authority summarizing the activities of the
31 Advisory Committee and any recommendations of the Advisory
32 Committee.

15 Quality Promotion of the Centers for Disease Control and
16 Prevention of the United States Department of Health and Human

29 paragraph (b) of subsection 4, including without limitation,

32 (1) For a medical facility, on or after October 15, 2010; and

35 Sec. 169. NRS 439.873 is hereby amended to read as follows:
36 439.873 1. A medical facility shall designate an officer or

38 the medical facility.
39 2. The person who is designated as the infection control officer
40 of a medical facility:
41 (a) Shall serve on the patient safety committee.
42 (b) Shall monitor the occurrences of infections at the medical
43 facility to determine the number and severity of infections.
44 (c) Shall report to the patient safety committee concerning the
45 number and severity of infections at the medical facility.

*SB494*

– 140 –
1 (d) Shall take such action as he or she determines is necessary to
2 prevent and control infections alleged to have occurred at the
3 medical facility.
4 (e) Shall carry out the provisions of the infection control
5 program adopted pursuant to NRS 439.865 and ensure compliance
6 with the program.
7 3. If a medical facility has 175 or more beds, the person who is
8 designated as the infection control officer of the medical facility
9 must be certified as an infection preventionist by the Certification
10 Board of Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc., or a successor
11 organization. A person may serve as the certified infection
12 preventionist for more than one medical facility if the facilities have
13 common ownership.
14 4. A medical facility that designates an infection control officer
15 who is not a certified infection preventionist must ensure that the
16 person has successfully completed a nationally recognized basic
17 training program in infection control, which may include, without
18 limitation, the program offered by the Association for Professionals
19 in Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc., or a successor
20 organization. A medical facility shall ensure that an infection
21 control officer completes at least 4 hours of continuing education
22 each year on topics relating to current practices in infection control
23 and prevention.
24 5. A medical facility shall ensure that it maintains a ratio of at

26 for every 100 occupied beds. The number of beds must be
27 determined based upon the most recent annual calendar-year
28 average reported by the medical facility to the Director of the

30 pursuant thereto.

12 (f) The manner in which and the locations where the population
13 served by the hospital will be able to obtain the health services that
14 were provided by the hospital during the 24 months following the
15 closure or conversion of the hospital.
16 4. The Director or the designee of the Director shall not
17 approve an application submitted pursuant to subsection 1 without
18 considering the information required to be submitted pursuant to
19 subsection 3.
20 5. The decision of the Director or the designee of the Director
21 pursuant to this section is a final decision for the purposes of
22 judicial review.
23 6. The provisions of this section do not apply to any person
24 who ceases to operate hospitals in this State.

*SB494*

– 161 –
1 (IV) Consent to the transfer has been given by the patient

8 physician working in the hospital is entitled to recover from that
9 hospital an amount equal to three times the charges for the treatment
10 provided that was billed by the physician, hospital or other health
11 facility which provided the treatment, plus reasonable attorney’s
12 fees and costs.

15 (a) When the patient is covered by an insurance policy or other

22 (c) When the hospital cannot provide the services needed by the
23 patient.
24  No transfer may be made pursuant to this subsection until the
25 patient’s condition has been stabilized to a degree that allows the
26 transfer without an additional risk to the patient.
27 5. As used in this section:
28 (a) “Emergency services and care” means medical screening,
29 examination and evaluation by a physician or, to the extent
30 permitted by a specific statute, by a person under the supervision of
31 a physician, to determine if an emergency medical condition or
32 active labor exists and, if it does, the care, treatment and surgery by
33 a physician necessary to relieve or eliminate the emergency medical
34 condition or active labor, within the capability of the hospital. As
35 used in this paragraph:
36 (1) “Active labor” means, in relation to childbirth, labor that
37 occurs when:
38 (I) There is inadequate time before delivery to transfer the
39 patient safely to another hospital; or
40 (II) A transfer may pose a threat to the health and safety
41 of the patient or the unborn child.
42 (2) “Emergency medical condition” means the presence of
43 acute symptoms of sufficient severity, including severe pain, such
44 that the absence of immediate medical attention could reasonably be
45 expected to result in:
-
*SB494*

– 162 –
1 (I) Placing the health of the patient in serious jeopardy;
2 (II) Serious impairment of bodily functions; or
3 (III) Serious dysfunction of any bodily organ or part.
4 (b) “Medically fit” means that the condition of the patient has
5 been sufficiently stabilized so that the patient may be safely
6 transported to another hospital, or is such that, in the determination
7 of the attending physician, the transfer of the patient constitutes an
8 acceptable risk. Such a determination must be based upon the
9 condition of the patient, the expected benefits, if any, to the patient
10 resulting from the transfer and whether the risks to the patient’s
11 health are outweighed by the expected benefits, and must be
12 documented in the patient’s records before the transfer.
13 6. If an allegation of a violation of the provisions of subsection

17 Authority shall conduct an investigation of the alleged violation.
18 Such a violation, in addition to any criminal penalties that may be
19 imposed, constitutes grounds for the denial, suspension or
20 revocation of such a license, or for the imposition of any sanction
21 prescribed by NRS 449.163.

14 Sec. 279. NRS 639.2327 is hereby amended to read as
15 follows:
16 639.2327 A facility for intermediate care or facility for skilled
17 nursing which is licensed as such by the Health Care Purchasing
18 and Compliance Division of [Public and Behavioral Health of the
19 Department of Health and Human Services] the Nevada Health
20 Authority and is registered with the Board pursuant to this chapter
21 may maintain a stock of drugs for emergency treatment of
22 inpatients, subject to the following conditions:
23 1. The Board shall by regulation determine the specific drugs
24 and the quantities thereof which may be maintained.
25 2. The emergency stock of drugs must be maintained at all
26 times in a solid, sealed container and the seal must remain intact
27 except when the drugs are needed for emergency treatment of a
28 patient in the facility. The sealed container must be stored at all
29 times in a locked compartment on the premises of the facility.
30 3. All drugs delivered to a facility must be signed for by the
31 nurse or other person in charge. An inventory of the stock of drugs
32 must be appended to the sealed container. Immediately after the
33 drugs are needed, the physician or registered nurse who breaks the
34 seal shall enter on the inventory sheet the following information:
35 (a) The date and time the sealed container is opened;
36 (b) The name of the patient for whom the drugs are to be used;
37 (c) The name of the patient’s physician or the physician who
38 directs the administration of the drugs, if different;
39 (d) An itemization of the drugs removed; and
40 (e) The signature of the person who opened the sealed container.
41 4. When the drugs have been removed and the information
42 required by subsection 3 has been entered on the inventory, the
43 physician or registered nurse shall immediately replace the container
44 in a locked compartment and shall notify the pharmaceutical
-
*SB494*

– 215 –
1 consultant, as soon as it is practical to do so, that the container has
2 been opened.
3 5. The sealed container and its contents at all times remain the
4 responsibility of the pharmaceutical consultant. Upon being notified
5 that the sealed container has been opened, or on the next business
6 day if notification is not received during business hours, but in no
7 event more than 48 hours following receipt of the notification, the
8 pharmaceutical consultant shall:
9 (a) Examine the inventory sheet;
10 (b) Replace the drugs removed;
11 (c) Secure a written prescription for the drugs replaced, if one is
12 required by law;
13 (d) Enter the name and quantity of the drugs so replaced on the
14 inventory sheet, together with the date and time of replacement;
15 (e) Reseal the container; and
16 (f) Sign the inventory sheet.
17 6. No person other than a licensed physician or registered nurse
18 may open the container or remove any drugs from the container.
19 7. The Board, its agents and inspectors may at all times have
20 access to the premises of the facility to determine compliance with
21 this section.

7 Sec. 283. NRS 640D.060 is hereby amended to read as
8 follows:
9 640D.060 “Music therapy” means the clinical use of music
10 interventions by a licensee to accomplish individualized goals
11 within a therapeutic relationship by a credentialed professional who
12 has completed a music therapy program approved by the [Board.]
13 Division. The term does not include:
14 1. The practice of psychology or medicine;
15 2. The psychological assessment or treatment of couples or
16 families;
17 3. The prescribing of drugs or electroconvulsive therapy;
18 4. The medical treatment of physical disease, injury or
19 deformity;
20 5. The diagnosis or psychological treatment of a psychotic
21 disorder;
22 6. The use of projective techniques in the assessment of
23 personality;
24 7. The use of psychological, neuropsychological, psychometric
25 assessment or clinical tests designed to identify or classify abnormal
26 or pathological human behavior or to determine intelligence,
27 personality, aptitude, interests or addictions;
28 8. The use of individually administered intelligence tests,
29 academic achievement tests or neuropsychological tests;
30 9. The use of psychotherapy to treat the concomitants of
31 organic illness;
32 10. The diagnosis of any physical or mental disorder; or
33 11. The evaluation of the effects of medical and psychotropic
34 drugs.

9 Authority to determine whether its vehicles and their operation are
10 safe.
11 6. An incorporated city, county or regional transportation
12 commission is not required to obtain a certificate of public
13 convenience and necessity to operate a system of public
14 transportation.
15 7. Before an incorporated city or a county enters into an
16 agreement with a common motor carrier for a system of public
17 transit that provides for the transportation of passengers that is
18 described in paragraph (c) or (d) of subsection 2 in an area of the
19 incorporated city or an area of the county, it must determine that:
20 (a) There are no other common motor carriers of passengers
21 who are authorized to provide such services in that area; or
22 (b) Although there are other common motor carriers of
23 passengers who are authorized to provide such services in the area,
24 the common motor carriers of passengers do not wish to provide, or
25 are not capable of providing, such services.
